","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ENGG0360","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ENGG0360 - Communicating in Engineering","description":"

The expectations and conventions applying to spoken and written communications within engineering and science. Different textual genres. Aspects of rhetoric. Ethical use of material. Formal language structure; grammar and syntax.


Students will improve their ability to collect and build ideas into coherent arguments, learn how to construct texts that demonstrate critical thinking, and develop their communication skills (speaking, listening, writing, & reading), in preparation for subsequent study in a professional context.


Students in a single Bachelor of Engineering degree can count this course towards their General Education requirements.

contentlets.description:
The expectations and conventions applying to spoken and written communications within engineering and science. Different textual genres. Aspects of rhetoric. Ethical use of material. Formal language structure; grammar and syntax.

Students will improve their ability to collect and build ideas into coherent arguments, learn how to construct texts that demonstrate critical thinking, and develop their communication skills (speaking, listening, writing, & reading), in preparation for subsequent study in a professional context.

Students in a single Bachelor of Engineering degree can count this course towards their General Education requirements.
contentlets.title: Communicating in Engineering

Introduction to Engineering Design and Innovation","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2021/DPST1071","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"show","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"DPST1071","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"UNSW Global","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"ENGG1000 - Introduction to Engineering Design and Innovation","description":"In this course, students will experience first hand one of the major things that engineers do: designing and building creative solutions to problems. They will learn to think the way that engineers think, coming up with good solutions to problems despite being limited by budget, time and resources, the requirement to also meet environmental and social objectives and of course the limitations of the laws of physics. This will help them to appreciate the central ideas of engineering design as an on-time, on-budget and fit for purpose solution to a poorly specified, open-ended problem. They will be assigned to a team to work over a ten week period to solve a practical problem. The projects on offer change from year to year. In doing all this they will start to build key skills for engineers that will be called upon repeatedly in their academic and professional lives, including concept development, critical thinking and evaluation skills, clear communication, research and information literacy skills and the skills involved in successfully functioning within a team environment to complete a given task.For further information please see ENGG1000","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f77b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Design Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"6","weighting":"15","description":"

Students keep a professional record and reflection on their design project work, which is reviewed by staff on a regular basis.

Assessment criteria will be relative to the task specification but should include written communication, design process/quality, teamwork/project management and reflection.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"1aa26c0cdbb6605055a93324f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"777b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7b7b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7f7b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1e95a0ccdbb6605055a93324f3961965","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Design Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Student teams submit a design proposal which reports on the problem definition, concept generation and concept evaluation design phases. The proposal also presents a plan for completing the project and includes any preliminary test results. 

Assessment criteria will be relative to the task specification but should include written communication, quality of design process/outcomes and project management. Team evaluation is used to ensure the equitable participation of members.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"1aa26c0cdbb6605055a93324f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"777b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"777b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7b7b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7f7b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7f7b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3b7bd084dbb6605055a93324f3961905","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Engineering Design Process","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Student teams present the process and outcomes of their problem definition and concept generation design phases.

Assessment criteria will be relative to the task specification but should include oral communication and quality of the design process and outcome. Team evaluation is used to ensure the equitable participation of members.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"1aa26c0cdbb6605055a93324f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"777b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7b7b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"408bd084dbb6605055a93324f396192d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Design Report and Competition","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

The performance of the student team's final prototypes is evaluated by judges against a set of project-specific criteria in a competition format. 

Student teams submit a formal report which communicates their final design outcomes, including relevant competition results. Assessment criteria will be relative to the task specification but should include written communication, quality of design process/outcomes. Team evaluation is used to ensure the equitable participation of members.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"1aa26c0cdbb6605055a93324f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"777b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"777b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7b7b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7f7b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7f7b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"408bd084dbb6605055a93324f3961934","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Impromptu Design Day","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"5","description":"

Students complete an impromptu design activity, working in teams to rapidly prototype a solution to a design challenge. Students are then assessed on an individual reflective writing task based on the activity, in a short-essay style. 

Assessment criteria will be relative to the task specification but should include written communication and reflection.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"1aa26c0cdbb6605055a93324f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"777b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"777b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7b7b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7f7b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7f7b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"488bd084dbb6605055a93324f396190e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Technical Stream","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"20","description":"

Students select a technical stream, with theory and practice assessed in relevant tasks (e.g. online quizzes, practical demonstrations, performance milestones and so on).

Assessment criteria will be relative to the technical task specification.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7f7b9084dbb6605055a93324f396199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"888bd084dbb6605055a93324f3961931","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ENGG1000.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: In this course, students will experience first hand one of the major things that engineers do: designing and building creative solutions to problems. They will learn to think the way that engineers think, coming up with good solutions to problems despite being limited by budget, time and resources, the requirement to also meet environmental and social objectives and of course the limitations of the laws of physics. This will help them to appreciate the central ideas of engineering design as an on-time, on-budget and fit for purpose solution to a poorly specified, open-ended problem. They will be assigned to a team to work over a ten week period to solve a practical problem. The projects on offer change from year to year.  In doing all this they will start to build key skills for engineers that will be called upon repeatedly in their academic and professional lives, including concept development, critical thinking and evaluation skills, clear communication, research and information literacy skills and the skills involved in successfully functioning within a team environment to complete a given task.For further information please see ENGG1000

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ENGG1100 - Grand Challenges for Engineering","description":"

These special projects are designed for highly motivated undergraduates seeking the opportunity to integrate specific curricular and co-curricular components into their undergraduate program, to provide them with superior preparation and experience in a project area.


Students will pursue research in a particular theme, explore interdisciplinary coursework, gain a global perspective, develop an entrepreneurial mindset, and give back to the community through service learning. Benefits for participating can include unique opportunities and experiences, mentoring by academic supervisors, guest speakers, and funding opportunities.


This course can count as an L1 elective or towards General Education.

contentlets.description:
These special projects are designed for highly motivated undergraduates seeking the opportunity to integrate specific curricular and co-curricular components into their undergraduate program, to provide them with superior preparation and experience in a project area.

Students will pursue research in a particular theme, explore interdisciplinary coursework, gain a global perspective, develop an entrepreneurial mindset, and give back to the community through service learning. Benefits for participating can include unique opportunities and experiences, mentoring by academic supervisors, guest speakers, and funding opportunities.

This course can count as an L1 elective or towards General Education.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ENGG1200 - Undergraduate Special Projects","description":"

These special projects are designed for highly motivated undergraduates seeking the opportunity to integrate specific curricular and co-curricular components into their undergraduate program, to provide them with superior preparation and experience in a project area.


Students will pursue research in a particular theme, explore interdisciplinary coursework, gain a global perspective, develop an entrepreneurial mindset, and give back to the community through service learning. Benefits for participating can include unique opportunities and experiences, mentoring by academic supervisors, guest speakers, and funding opportunities.


This course can count as an L1 elective for Engineering students or towards General Education for non-Engineering students.

contentlets.description:
These special projects are designed for highly motivated undergraduates seeking the opportunity to integrate specific curricular and co-curricular components into their undergraduate program, to provide them with superior preparation and experience in a project area.

Students will pursue research in a particular theme, explore interdisciplinary coursework, gain a global perspective, develop an entrepreneurial mindset, and give back to the community through service learning. Benefits for participating can include unique opportunities and experiences, mentoring by academic supervisors, guest speakers, and funding opportunities.

This course can count as an L1 elective for Engineering students or towards General Education for non-Engineering students.

Engineering Mechanics","description":"

This is the  foundational mechanics course for students in Aerospace, Civil, Environmental, Manufacturing, Mechanical, Mechatronics and Mining Engineering, with content as follows: Revision of vectors, resultants and components, moments; The free body diagram; Equilibrium of planar rigid objects; Equilibrium of systems of co-planar multi-force members and planar trusses; Frames and Machines; Springs; Friction; Mass centre, centroids, distributed forces; Internal forces in beams; Introduction to 3-dimensional statics; Plane particle kinematics, including curvilinear and relative motion; Plane particle kinetics, including equations of motion, work-energy-power, friction, impulse-momentum, impact; Kinetics of systems of particles; Introduction to plane kinematics of rigid bodies, types of rigid body motion (translation, rotation about a fixed axis); Mass moment of inertia, parallel axis theorem, moment of inertia for various shapes, Introduction to plane kinetics of rigid bodies, rigid body in plane motion, equations of motion, work-energy for a rigid body.

A course in optimization and modelling for first year engineering students who desire a higher capability in the application of the modelling of engineering systems, and seek to acquire a set of optimization tools that can be applied to various engineering applications. The course will introduce fundamental engineering systems concepts and methods with real-world projects related to critical contemporary issues. The course includes lectures on the following topics: complex systems, network modelling, system dynamics, optimization methods, infrastructure system design and behaviour and decision making.


This course in intended for first year engineering students.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"390e257bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

The Assignment will be released in Week 7 and will be due in Week 9. The assignment will consists of a series of problems and focus on students implementing AMPL scripts and algorithms to solve infrastructure systems decision problems extending those introduced during the course. The assignment will assess the expected learning outcomes and will be assessed based on technical accuracy, clarity in reporting and presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"310e257bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3d0e257bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7d0e257bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b90e257bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f10e257bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2d0e257bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly Moodle Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Weekly Moodle Quizzes will be provided totalling in 20% of the course mark. These quizzes will consist of small, customized problems covering the material introduced during the current week. The weekly quizzes will assess the expected learning outcomes and will be assessed based on technical accuracy and participation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"310e257bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3d0e257bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7d0e257bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b90e257bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f10e257bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"510e257bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961999","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

The Assignment will be released in Week 4 and will be due in Week 6. The assignment will consists of a series of problems and focus on students solving infrastructure systems decision problems in AMPL presented during the course. The assignment will assess the expected learning outcomes and will be assessed based on technical accuracy, clarity in reporting and presentation.

The final written examination will be in the conventional closed book format covering all topics introduced throughout the course. The final examination will consists of a series of problems and focus on theoretical and methodological concepts presented within the lectures as well as within previous assessments. The final examination will assess the expected learning outcomes and will be assessed based on technical accuracy, clarity in reporting and presentation.

contentlets.description:
A course in optimization and modelling for first year engineering students who desire a higher capability in the application of the modelling of engineering systems, and seek to acquire a set of optimization tools that can be applied to various engineering applications. The course will introduce fundamental engineering systems concepts and methods with real-world projects related to critical contemporary issues. The course includes lectures on the following topics: complex systems, network modelling, system dynamics, optimization methods, infrastructure system design and behaviour and decision making.

This course in intended for first year engineering students.

The objective of this course is for students to acquire computing skills for solving problems in engineering. The course will develop the students' proficiency in a high level programming language and in using programming for problem solving. Topics: algorithms, program structure (statements, selection, iteration, functions), data types, arrays and matrices, reading and writing files, testing, code quality, simulation, animation, visualisation. The course includes practical work in labs and programming projects.

Mechanics of Solids 1","description":"

This course provides an introduction to the fundamentals to the mechanics of solids. The topics include properties of plane cross-sectional shapes including centroid & principal second moment of area; concepts of stress and strain; 2D transformation of stresses and strains under axis rotation; principal stresses and strains; Mohr’s circle of stress and strain; stress-strain relationships; elasticity, thermal strain, Poisson’s ratio and Hooke’s Law; bars under axial force; Indeterminate axial force systems; elastic bending stress formula; composite beams; deflections due to bending; step functions; simple indeterminate beams; shear flow; shear centre; torsion of circular shafts and box sections.

Fluid Mechanics for Engineers","description":"

The objective of ENGG2500 is to introduce engineering students to the principles of fluid mechanics. Topics discussed include Fluid properties. Hydrostatics. Buoyancy. Pressures in fluid systems. Principles of mass conservation. Steady flow energy equations. Flow measurement. Forces and momentum in flowing fluids. Dimensional analysis, similarity and physical modelling. Pipe flow. Incompressible laminar and turbulent flow in pipes; friction factor. Elementary boundary layer flow; skin friction and drag. Pumps and turbines. Pump and pipeline system characteristics.

Several open book online quizzes will encourage continuous student learning throughout the course. The quizzes are done either at home, library or on campus. Marks are awarded for correct answers. The topics covered in each online quiz are listed on the Moodle course page. The purpose of online Quiz will be to provide a clear study framework. It will also provide the opportunity to develop self-learning and problem solving skills. Class problem sessions will serve as a basis for discussion with demonstrators and lecturers. Some Online Quizzes will be also test the understanding of the course theory and the required background knowledge prior to their lab classes optimising their learning and participation during the lab class.

Several online lab modules integrate the lab classes of the course with fundamental understanding of the course concepts as well as pre- and postlab assessments. Prior to the lab classes, students will study the theory of the lab class and instruction videos of the experiments in the lab classes on the Moodle course page. During the compulsory lab classes (which students complete in small groups), students collect lab data. After the lab class, the collected lab data will be used for individual numerical online assessments on the Moodle course page. Students will use their lab data in a series of guided calculation questions and feedback will be provided after all students have completed the online assessment for each lab class.

After the lab class, the collected lab data will be used for individual numerical online assessments on the Moodle course page. Students will use their lab data in a series of guided calculation questions and feedback will be provided after all students have completed the online assessment for each lab class.

contentlets.description: The objective of ENGG2500 is to introduce engineering students to the principles of fluid mechanics. Topics discussed include Fluid properties. Hydrostatics. Buoyancy. Pressures in fluid systems. Principles of mass conservation. Steady flow energy equations. Flow measurement. Forces and momentum in flowing fluids. Dimensional analysis, similarity and physical modelling. Pipe flow. Incompressible laminar and turbulent flow in pipes; friction factor. Elementary boundary layer flow; skin friction and drag. Pumps and turbines. Pump and pipeline system characteristics.
contentlets.title: Fluid Mechanics for Engineers

In either case a final grade is withheld until the final course is completed."}],"credit_points_header":"2 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ENGG2600 - Engineering Vertically Integrated Project","description":"

This course is designed for highly motivated undergraduates seeking the opportunity to integrate specific curricular and co-curricular components into their undergraduate program, to provide them with enhanced preparation and experience in the areas of Leadership and Project Management as it relates to engineering research and/or design, and thus giving them a headstart when seeking employment.   


The courses run across three consecutive terms within a single calendar year: T1,2 and 3 (2 UoC per Term) for a total of 6 UoC at the end, which enables students to extend their project-based learning experience beyond a single term. 


You must complete all three terms of the course and satisfy all assessment requirements as set out by the course coordinator to receive full course credit. Partial credits will not be given.


Students will pursue research or project execution in a particular theme, explore interdisciplinary course-work, gain a global perspective, develop an entrepreneurial mindset, or give back to the community through service learning. Benefits for participating can include unique opportunities and experiences, mentoring by academic supervisors, guest speakers, and funding opportunities and engagement with industry partners.


Under the guidance of academic mentors and industry mentors, this course provides a vehicle for guided but independent group project work on varying briefs. The learning and effort in the course is largely team-based, with team-members ideally being drawn from different discipline areas. Students will develop their skills in critical thinking, problem definition, creative and systematic design, precise written and oral technical communication skills, and professional skills including communication and team organisation and coordination. The course allows students to design, build and research a variety of projects.


ENGG2600 is the first course in a "vertical" sequence of project-based learning courses, with ENGG3600 and ENGG4600 also offered, and thereby allows students an opportunity to engage again at a more senior level and attain more advanced skills.


Prerequisite conditions:
UNSW Engineering students: (Successful completion of ENGG1000 or enrolled in a Food Science or Computer Science plan) AND successful completion of at least 42 UOC AND enrolled in a program offered by the Faculty of Engineering.


UNSW Medicine students (program 3805 or 3856) must have demonstrated adequate performance with teamwork in every course during their first year to be eligible to participate in Vertically Integrated Courses: ENGG2600, ENGG3600, ENGG4600.


Medicine students must also be eligible to overload during year 3 based on the general education requirements for BSc (Med) Hons.


Students from other UNSW Faculties may apply to join the ChallENG program as a General Education elective. Students should ensure their program requires a General Education elective prior to application.


Note: WAM will be considered in all student applications for enrolment in this course.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ba7ee302db6c2050be4672f5f3961977","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Self-Reflection and Peer Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Part A Self-reflection (10%): Students will complete a self-reflection in the form of a SWOT analysis in order to give self-feedback on how students can improve their work.

\n

Part B Team Evaluation (5%): Students will complete a team evaluation each term to understand how they are working with their peers. This assessment can also act as an impetus for reflecting on where students can improve their teamwork.

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ENGG2997 - Engineering Work Integrated Learning","description":"

This course provides students enrolled in degrees without Industrial Training with an opportunity to engage in Work Integrated Learning (WIL). Students will engage in authentic, purposeful, partnered, supervised and assessed work learning experiences that integrate academic learning with its application in the workplace as part of their program of study. It provides the means to ‘do in context’ rather than developing practical skills alone; it enables students to develop work readiness skills to workplace standards and enhances employability. Academic study is paired with between 15 - 50 work days in a self-sourced placement.

Students will explore various skills and processes associated with development and execution of a scientific and/or engineering type project. In doing so, they will build on authentic work integrated learning experiences, and develop relevant career skills for securing future placements. These skills and processes include project management of engineering projects, understanding requirements of clients, effective communication, and interaction with a wide range of stakeholders, other disciplines, professions, and people and presenting yourself both orally and in a written form. It also includes extension into ethical behaviour and organisational theory with an overall aim to develop students’ employability

Enrolment in the course is restricted to students who are:


  • Enrolled in a Faculty of Engineering single or dual degree that does not require Industrial Training (co-op students are also ineligible)
  • Have completed a minimum 72 UoC
  • Have a confirmed WIL placement

contentlets.description:
This course provides students enrolled in degrees without Industrial Training with an opportunity to engage in Work Integrated Learning (WIL). Students will engage in authentic, purposeful, partnered, supervised and assessed work learning experiences that integrate academic learning with its application in the workplace as part of their program of study. It provides the means to ‘do in context’ rather than developing practical skills alone; it enables students to develop work readiness skills to workplace standards and enhances employability. Academic study is paired with between 15 - 50 work days in a self-sourced placement.

Students will explore various skills and processes associated with development and execution of a scientific and/or engineering type project. In doing so, they will build on authentic work integrated learning experiences, and develop relevant career skills for securing future placements. These skills and processes include project management of engineering projects, understanding requirements of clients, effective communication, and interaction with a wide range of stakeholders, other disciplines, professions, and people and presenting yourself both orally and in a written form. It also includes extension into ethical behaviour and organisational theory with an overall aim to develop students’ employability

Enrolment in the course is restricted to students who are:

  • Enrolled in a Faculty of Engineering single or dual degree that does not require Industrial Training (co-op students are also ineligible)
  • Have completed a minimum 72 UoC
  • Have a confirmed WIL placement

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ENGG3001","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ENGG3001 - Fundamentals of Humanitarian Engineering","description":"

This course enables engineers to analyse and design infrastructure and appropriate technology to support the well-being and welfare of individuals and communities in disadvantaged circumstances. This includes developing countries as well as marginalised or remote communities in Australia. The course provides students with frameworks to analyse and respond to complex multi-disciplinary engineering problems. The concept of appropriate technology and capacity building are fundamental to this course. It provides context to the planning and design of infrastructure and technology in areas such as water and waste management, energy supply and distribution, assistive technologies; and provides a series of case studies to illustrate humanitarian engineering principles.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5ebcc1b3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Simulation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Participatory simulation activity exploring the roles of engineers, politicians and the community in development projects. Assessment will be based on contribution, engagement and awareness of the concepts encountered in lectures to date.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"52bcc1b3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5abcc1b3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"02bcc1b3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Humanitarian Engineering Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Part 1 - Provide a reflection on how your understanding has changed of the importance of geography and politics and their interactions with engineering and specifically Humanitarian Engineering.
Part 2 - Provide a reflection on  the skills and opportunities that need to be identified and achieved in order to have a successful career as a humanitarian engineer.

Presentations will be assessed on content and communication style including technical information, clarity of speech, clarity and usefulness of visual aids

contentlets.description: This course enables engineers to analyse and design infrastructure and appropriate technology to support the well-being and welfare of individuals and communities in disadvantaged circumstances. This includes developing countries as well as marginalised or remote communities in Australia. The course provides students with frameworks to analyse and respond to complex multi-disciplinary engineering problems. The concept of appropriate technology and capacity building are fundamental to this course. It provides context to the planning and design of infrastructure and technology in areas such as water and waste management, energy supply and distribution, assistive technologies; and provides a series of case studies to illustrate humanitarian engineering principles.
contentlets.title: Fundamentals of Humanitarian Engineering

This course provides students with a detailed understanding of the technical design factors and technology used in different vehicles. Throughout the course, students learn about the engineering science underpinning vehicle design and the resultant advantages and disadvantages associated with various mobility technologies. A series of structured tutorials assists students to further develop their understanding relating to key areas of automotive design, vehicle handling, track vehicle steering and suspension design. The course is designed to provide students with a working level understanding of the fundamental engineering science and technology used in the design of modern vehicles.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c8faa173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96199d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Assignments will be used to provide a clear study framework for the students, in addition to the opportunity to develop self-learning and problem-solving skills. The assignment questions for each week will be posted on Moodle in advance. Multiple tutorial sessions will be held each week to serve as a platform of discussion between the students and the tutors. The students will be asked to look over and attempt the assignments before the tutorial sessions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3beaa173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"77eaa173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961994","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b3eaa173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2beaa173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961983","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Technical report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

A case study will be used to help students enhance their understanding of the fundamental course concepts. A field trip will also be organized as part of the course. The students will be asked to study relevant theories that are posted on Moodle in advance. Throughout the course, the students will be asked to undertake comparative analysis of the automotive subsystems that are presented to them and submit a individual technical report after. The students will be provided with guided questions and feedback to support their technical writing.

In either case a final grade is withheld until the final course is completed."}],"credit_points_header":"3 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ENGG3060 - Maker Games","description":"

Under the guidance of academic mentors and industry mentors, this course provides a vehicle for guided but independent group project work on a client-provided brief. The learning and effort in the course is largely group-based, with group members ideally being drawn from different discipline areas. Students will develop their skills in critical thinking, problem definition, creative and systematic design, precise written and oral technical communication skills, and professional skills including communication, team organisation and coordination. The course allows students to undertake and make prototype design and construction as part of the final phase of The Maker Games.


In 2020 the Maker Games will focus on design projects relating to physical therapy, rehabilitation equipment, the design of internal and external prostheses, and other related areas. All Engineering students are welcome to apply.


This course runs over two consecutive terms (3 UoC per term) for a total of 6 UoC at the end. Students must enrol in and successfully complete both terms of the course to receive full course credit. Partial credits will not be given.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8f253988dbf35050358b403c3a9619ed","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project design","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Teams present a refined problem statement, background/related knowledge, conceptual design, three design alternatives for each component of the conceptual design, a project plan, and a detailed description of what 'success' looks like. This should be early in the term, typically Week 3.

Individual component: 10%

Team component: 5%

Midway through the term, teams present a progress report including motivation, refined problem statement, conceptual design, background knowledge/competitive analysis, proposed design, progress to date, testing/evaluation of design components, user feedback, and plans. This must include a demonstration of the prototype to that point. Every team member must present, and their individual contribution must be clear.

Individual component: 20%

Team component: 5%

Teams present their final detailed design (including how it addresses the problem statement and how it has been evaluated) and demonstrate their prototype. Every team member must present, and their individual contribution must be clear.

Individual component: 20%

Team component: 10%

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"03253988dbf35050358b403c3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"07253988dbf35050358b403c3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0b253988dbf35050358b403c3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0b253988dbf35050358b403c3a9619f1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a7257988dbf35050358b403c3a961938","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

At the end of term, teams present the precise specification of their final detailed design, a clear presentation of the evaluation of the prototype, including all preliminary/unit testing, and the findings and conclusion, as well as the (improved-upon) elements from the Project Design report. The report must clearly show improvements in response to feedback from throughout the course, but in particular from the Project Design report.

Individual component: 20%

Team component: 10%

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"03253988dbf35050358b403c3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"03253988dbf35050358b403c3a9619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"07253988dbf35050358b403c3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0b253988dbf35050358b403c3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0b253988dbf35050358b403c3a9619f1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"df253988dbf35050358b403c3a9619ff","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly updates","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"10","description":"

It is expected that every week, teams will be meeting online/face-to-face between 1-2 times, besides meeting with the academic/industry mentor. To make any real progress, teams will need to make notes (minutes) on progress/design/issues/planning, including an update on progress from each individual team member, and record action items, which will be clearly defined, be assigned to one or more team members and have a deadline. Each team must record these and upload one weekly update document per week on Moodle (if one of several team members are getting course credit).

Individual component: 70%

Team component: 30%

contentlets.description:
Under the guidance of academic mentors and industry mentors, this course provides a vehicle for guided but independent group project work on a client-provided brief. The learning and effort in the course is largely group-based, with group members ideally being drawn from different discipline areas. Students will develop their skills in critical thinking, problem definition, creative and systematic design, precise written and oral technical communication skills, and professional skills including communication, team organisation and coordination. The course allows students to undertake and make prototype design and construction as part of the final phase of The Maker Games.

In 2020 the Maker Games will focus on design projects relating to physical therapy, rehabilitation equipment, the design of internal and external prostheses, and other related areas. All Engineering students are welcome to apply.

This course runs over two consecutive terms (3 UoC per term) for a total of 6 UoC at the end. Students must enrol in and successfully complete both terms of the course to receive full course credit. Partial credits will not be given.

In either case a final grade is withheld until the final course is completed."}],"credit_points_header":"2 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ENGG3600 - Engineering Vertically Integrated Project","description":"

This course is designed for highly motivated undergraduates seeking the opportunity to integrate specific curricular and co-curricular components into their undergraduate program, to provide them with superior preparation and experience in the areas of Leadership and Project Management thus giving them a headstart when seeking employment. 


The courses run across three consecutive terms within a single calendar year: T1,2 and 3 (2 UoC per Term)for a total of 6 UoC at the end, which enables students to extend their project-based learning experience beyond a single term. 


You must complete all three terms of the course and satisfy all assessment requirements as set out by the course coordinator to receive full course credit. Partial credits will not be given.


Students will pursue research in a particular theme, explore interdisciplinary coursework, gain a global perspective, develop an entrepreneurial mindset, and give back to the community through service learning. Benefits for participating can include unique opportunities and experiences, mentoring by academic supervisors, guest speakers, and funding opportunities and engagement with industry partners.


Under the guidance of academic mentors and industry mentors, this course provides a vehicle for guided but independent group project work on varying briefs. The learning and effort in the course is largely group-based, with group members ideally being drawn from different discipline areas. Students will develop their skills in critical thinking, problem definition, creative and systematic design, precise written and oral technical communication skills, and professional skills including communication and team organisation and coordination. The course allows students to design, build and research a variety of projects. 


Prerequisite conditions:


UNSW Engineering students prerequisites: (Successful completion of ENGG1000 or enrolled in a Food Science or Computer Science plan) AND successful completion of at least 72 UOC AND enrolled in a program offered by the Faculty of Engineering.


UNSW Medicine students (program 3805 or 3856) must have demonstrated adequate performance with teamwork in every course during their first year to be eligible to participate in Vertically Integrated Courses: ENGG2600, ENGG3600, ENGG4600.


Medicine students must also be eligible to overload during year 3 based on the general education requirements for BSc (Med) Hons.


Students from other UNSW Faculties may apply to join the ChallENG program as a General Education elective. Students should ensure their program requires a General Education elective prior to application.


Note: WAM will be considered in all student applications for enrolment in this course.

Students will regularly record their meetings, design work, graphs, drawings, etc. in their notebook to document their project management skills and improving their ability to work independently.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d07e505edbec2050be4672f5f39619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"d47e505edbec2050be4672f5f39619a9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"507e505edbec2050be4672f5f39619c6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Self-Reflection and Peer Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"
 
Part A Self-reflection (10%): Students will complete a self-reflection in the form of a SWOT analysis in order to give self-feedback on how students can improve their work.
 
Part B Team Evaluation (5%): Students will complete a team evaluation each term to understand how they are working with their peers. This assessment can also act as an impetus for reflecting on where students can improve their teamwork.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d07e505edbec2050be4672f5f39619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d47e505edbec2050be4672f5f39619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d47e505edbec2050be4672f5f39619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"dc7e505edbec2050be4672f5f39619a8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"687e905edbec2050be4672f5f3961906","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Technical","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"60","description":"

Students will present their project work as written and/or oral format as determined with their project coordinator.

The learning and effort in the course is largely group-based, with group members ideally being drawn from different discipline areas. The course allows students to design, build and research a variety of projects.

This fourth year elective course allows students to deliver a project, of their design, that engages the strength of cross-disciplinary student teams. Students will develop, manage, solve and report on a project, or solve a significant problem, that they initiate. The course develops project and planning skills and introduces student to the concept of 'success' criteria and 'failure' criteria. The project requires that students work in cross-disciplinary teams with the skill-set required to undertake identified tasks.


It is expected that teams will consist of four students crossing a minimum of three different discipline skill sets across single or dual engineering degrees. Teams of more than four students may be approved subject to a determination that the team skills match the project need and that skills are not excessively duplicated. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"99239adadbaa9810eb6b147a3a961919","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project design","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"5","description":"

Pitching of project to Teaching and Learning Committee. This includes:

  • Project design and identification of project participants;
  • Project plan and objectives, including: context; strategy; activities; outputs and milestone schedule; outcomes; risk analysis; budget planning; project management and reporting; dissemination of results;
  • Identification of deliverables including reporting, communication and dissemination of findings;
  • Clear definitions of ‘what success looks like’ and ‘what failure looks like;
  • Identifications of approvals needed (fieldwork/ethics/SWPs, etc); and
  • Identification of utilisation parties.

Teams will define the project and put together cross-disciplinary teams with the skill set needed for a successful conclusion and with consideration of workload and deliverables.

Assessment: Report and presentation

Group Assessment 5%

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9123dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a96196d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9123dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9523dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a96196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9923dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9923dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3123dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a961981","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

At the end of session, student teams will provide a final, comprehensive, report for assessment addressing all project components and agreed deliverables.

Report submitted a week prior to panel assessment. The report is to be presented as a series of Chapters of an 'Edited Book' - one Chapter by each individual.

Group is to write an Introduction Chapter to the Project and a Outcomes Chapter. Group 10%

Group members will be interviewed, individuality, on the outcomes, on contribution and on their tasks - evaluations are individual. A mark will be derived as a combination of interview and their written contribution (Chapter). Individual 40%

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"9123dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9123dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"9123dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"9923dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a96196d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9923dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a961971","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final presentation, inspection and reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Teams will present their project outcomes to a sub-panel of the School Teaching and Learning committee. The presentation may consist of a formal presentation of the project outcomes and/or an informal presentation of the delivered component(s).

Assessment against agreed outcomes at "project design" stage. Group Assessment: 10%

Each group member will submit a report reflecting on the outcomes and learning experience, against stated criteria. Individual assessment: 10%

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"9123dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9123dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"9123dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"9923dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a96196d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e523dadadbaa9810eb6b147a3a96197a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Progress report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

At midway, teams will present a progress report to a sub-panel of the School Teaching and Learning committee. The assessment consists of a formal written report and an oral presentation component.

Oral presentation: Group 5%

Report chapter drafts to be submitted prior to committee interview (individually) - group members interviewed by committee and feedback and mark provided (15% - individual)

This course provides students with the opportunity to undertake a design project related to Humanitarian Engineering. The course will be problem based, with context aligned with clearly identified needs for a marginalised community, either locally or internationally. The course is intended to be predominantly team-based with groups working on humanitarian related challenges, as approved by the course coordinator.

Projects could include any or all of the following components as appropriate to the identified problem:


  • background review of needs, context
  • development of potential solutions, including review of existing data, research and technologies as appropriate
  • evaluation of solutions
  • economic
  • social
  • environmental
  • technical
  • possible prototyping and/or lab investigations and/or field work
  • implementation strategy including involvement of the local community and consideration of long term sustainability.

Students will be encouraged to undertake community consultation e.g. via interviews or surveys or similar research to assist in the evaluation of solutions. The course is structured as independent project work with regularly scheduled meetings with an assigned academic advisor and/or industry mentor.

Weekly journal documenting learning and observations, meeting minutes and personal reflections.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"07057593db465410358b403c3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0b057593db465410358b403c3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"4705b993db465410358b403c3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4705b993db465410358b403c3a9619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4f05b993db465410358b403c3a9619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4f05b993db465410358b403c3a9619fd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6705f993db465410358b403c3a961920","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"55","description":"

The final report is a summary of the group's outcomes for the project. The report should be prepared and/or edited as a group and provide a holistic summary of the project aims, background, results and conclusions. The contribution of each student to the report will be assessed by peers and the academic mentor.

contentlets.description:
This course provides students with the opportunity to undertake a design project related to Humanitarian Engineering. The course will be problem based, with context aligned with clearly identified needs for a marginalised community, either locally or internationally. The course is intended to be predominantly team-based with groups working on humanitarian related challenges, as approved by the course coordinator.

Projects could include any or all of the following components as appropriate to the identified problem:

  • background review of needs, context
  • development of potential solutions, including review of existing data, research and technologies as appropriate
  • evaluation of solutions
  • economic
  • social
  • environmental
  • technical
  • possible prototyping and/or lab investigations and/or field work
  • implementation strategy including involvement of the local community and consideration of long term sustainability.

Students will be encouraged to undertake community consultation e.g. via interviews or surveys or similar research to assist in the evaluation of solutions. The course is structured as independent project work with regularly scheduled meetings with an assigned academic advisor and/or industry mentor.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ENGG4103","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ENGG4103 - International Humanitarian Response","description":"

This course provides understanding and preparation in international humanitarian response within the context of humanitarian practice for Engineers. The course consists of a series of lectures and workshops held at UNSW Kensington with an embedded one week field exercise in Mount Macedon Victoria in partnership with RedR Australia. Successful completion of the activities results in RedR accreditation of the participant. RedR prepares and deploys skilled people to help communities and government agencies plan, prepare, rebuild and recover before, during and after crises and conflict. The RedR course is embedded in a series of lectures and workshops delivered at UNSW Kensington before and after the 1 week course. The theory and practice covered in the lectures and workshops provide a depth of knowledge and problem solving on humanitarian disaster response and recovery. This will build on the ‘ENGG3001 Fundamentals of Engineering’ and complement the core principles of humanitarianism, its history, current design, SPHERE application, and simulation role play for disaster recovery and conflict scenarios delivered by RedR Australia. Workshops will focus on group work involving rapid decision making and communication as well as enhancing self-reflection techniques to incorporate knowledge and scenarios experienced throughout the course. Students will work in teams to maximise learning outcomes and develop their communication skills.

In either case a final grade is withheld until the final course is completed."}],"credit_points_header":"2 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ENGG4600 - Engineering Vertically Integrated Project","description":"

This course is designed for highly motivated undergraduates seeking the opportunity to integrate specific curricular and co-curricular components into their undergraduate program, to provide them with superior preparation and experience in the areas of Leadership and Project Management thus giving them a headstart when seeking employment.   


The courses run across three consecutive terms within a single calendar year: T1,2 and 3 (2 UoC per Term) for a total of 6 UoC at the end, which enables students to extend their project-based learning experience beyond a single term. 


You must complete all three terms of the course and satisfy all assessment requirements as set out by the course coordinator to receive full course credit. Partial credits will not be given.


Students will pursue research in a particular theme, explore interdisciplinary coursework, gain a global perspective, develop an entrepreneurial mindset, and give back to the community through service learning. Benefits for participating can include unique opportunities and experiences, mentoring by academic supervisors, guest speakers, and funding opportunities and engagement with industry partners.


Under the guidance of academic mentors and industry mentors, this course provides a vehicle for guided but independent group project work on varying briefs. The learning and effort in the course is largely group-based, with group members ideally being drawn from different discipline areas. Students will develop their skills in critical thinking, problem definition, creative and systematic design, precise written and oral technical communication skills, and professional skills including communication and team organisation and coordination. The course allows students to design, build and research a variety of projects. 


Prerequisite conditions:


UNSW Engineering students prerequisites: (Successful completion of ENGG1000 or enrolled in a Food Science or Computer Science plan) AND successful completion of at least 114 UOC AND enrolled in a program offered by the Faculty of Engineering.


UNSW Medicine students (program 3805 or 3856) must have demonstrated adequate performance with teamwork in every course during their first year to be eligible to participate in Vertically Integrated Courses: ENGG2600, ENGG3600, ENGG4600.


Medicine students must also be eligible to overload during year 3 based on the general education requirements for BSc (Med) Hons.


Students from other UNSW Faculties may apply to join the ChallENG program as a General Education elective. Students should ensure their program requires a General Education elective prior to application.


Note: WAM will be considered in all student applications for enrolment in this course.

Students will regularly record their meetings, design work, graphs, drawings, etc. in their notebook to document their project management skills and improving their ability to work independently.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"67f0b382db6c2050be4672f5f3961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6ff0b382db6c2050be4672f5f396194f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"33f0b382db6c2050be4672f5f3961956","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Communication","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will present their project work as written and/or oral format as determined with their project coordinator.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6ff0b382db6c2050be4672f5f396194f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"73f0b382db6c2050be4672f5f3961953","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Self-Reflection and Peer Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Part A Self-reflection (10%): Students will complete a self-reflection in the form of a SWOT analysis in order to give self-feedback on how students can improve their work.

\n

Part B Team Evaluation (5%): Students will complete a team evaluation each term to understand how they are working with their peers. This assessment can also act as an impetus for reflecting on where students can improve their teamwork.

Students will complete their major deliverable/s for assessment.

contentlets.description:
This course is designed for highly motivated undergraduates seeking the opportunity to integrate specific curricular and co-curricular components into their undergraduate program, to provide them with superior preparation and experience in the areas of Leadership and Project Management thus giving them a headstart when seeking employment.

Students will pursue research in a particular theme, explore interdisciplinary coursework, gain a global perspective, develop an entrepreneurial mindset, and give back to the community through service learning. Benefits for participating can include unique opportunities and experiences, mentoring by academic supervisors, guest speakers, and funding opportunities and engagement with industry partners.

Under the guidance of academic mentors and industry mentors, this course provides a vehicle for guided but independent group project work on varying briefs. The learning and effort in the course is largely group-based, with group members ideally being drawn from different discipline areas. Students will develop their skills in critical thinking, problem definition, creative and systematic design, precise written and oral technical communication skills, and professional skills including communication and team organisation and coordination. The course allows students to design, build and research a variety of projects. 

Prerequisite conditions:

UNSW Engineering students prerequisites: (Successful completion of ENGG1000 or enrolled in a Food Science or Computer Science plan) AND successful completion of at least 114 UOC AND enrolled in a program offered by the Faculty of Engineering.

Medicine students must also be eligible to overload during year 3 based on the general education requirements for BSc (Med) Hons.

Students from other UNSW Faculties may apply to join the ChallENG program as a General Education elective. Students should ensure their program requires a General Education elective prior to application.

Note: WAM will be considered in all student applications for enrolment in this course.

In either case a final grade is withheld until the final course is completed."}],"credit_points_header":"2 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ENGG4600 - Engineering Vertically Integrated Project","description":"

This course is designed for highly motivated undergraduates seeking the opportunity to integrate specific curricular and co-curricular components into their undergraduate program, to provide them with superior preparation and experience in the areas of Leadership and Project Management thus giving them a headstart when seeking employment.   


The courses run across three consecutive terms within a single calendar year: T1,2 and 3 (2 UoC per Term) for a total of 6 UoC at the end, which enables students to extend their project-based learning experience beyond a single term. 


You must complete all three terms of the course and satisfy all assessment requirements as set out by the course coordinator to receive full course credit. Partial credits will not be given.


Students will pursue research in a particular theme, explore interdisciplinary coursework, gain a global perspective, develop an entrepreneurial mindset, and give back to the community through service learning. Benefits for participating can include unique opportunities and experiences, mentoring by academic supervisors, guest speakers, and funding opportunities and engagement with industry partners.


Under the guidance of academic mentors and industry mentors, this course provides a vehicle for guided but independent group project work on varying briefs. The learning and effort in the course is largely group-based, with group members ideally being drawn from different discipline areas. Students will develop their skills in critical thinking, problem definition, creative and systematic design, precise written and oral technical communication skills, and professional skills including communication and team organisation and coordination. The course allows students to design, build and research a variety of projects. 


Prerequisite conditions:


UNSW Engineering students prerequisites: (Successful completion of ENGG1000 or enrolled in a Food Science or Computer Science plan) AND successful completion of at least 114 UOC AND enrolled in a program offered by the Faculty of Engineering.


UNSW Medicine students (program 3805 or 3856) must have demonstrated adequate performance with teamwork in every course during their first year to be eligible to participate in Vertically Integrated Courses: ENGG2600, ENGG3600, ENGG4600.


Medicine students must also be eligible to overload during year 3 based on the general education requirements for BSc (Med) Hons.


Students from other UNSW Faculties may apply to join the ChallENG program as a General Education elective. Students should ensure their program requires a General Education elective prior to application.


Note: WAM will be considered in all student applications for enrolment in this course.

Students will regularly record their meetings, design work, graphs, drawings, etc. in their notebook to document their project management skills and improving their ability to work independently.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"67f0b382db6c2050be4672f5f3961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6ff0b382db6c2050be4672f5f396194f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"33f0b382db6c2050be4672f5f3961956","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Communication","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will present their project work as written and/or oral format as determined with their project coordinator.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6ff0b382db6c2050be4672f5f396194f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"73f0b382db6c2050be4672f5f3961953","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Self-Reflection and Peer Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Part A Self-reflection (10%): Students will complete a self-reflection in the form of a SWOT analysis in order to give self-feedback on how students can improve their work.

\n

Part B Team Evaluation (5%): Students will complete a team evaluation each term to understand how they are working with their peers. This assessment can also act as an impetus for reflecting on where students can improve their teamwork.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"67f0b382db6c2050be4672f5f396194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6ff0b382db6c2050be4672f5f396194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e7f03382db6c2050be4672f5f39619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"eff03382db6c2050be4672f5f39619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7bf0b382db6c2050be4672f5f3961959","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Technical","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"60","description":"

Students will complete their major deliverable/s for assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"67f0b382db6c2050be4672f5f396194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"67f0b382db6c2050be4672f5f3961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6ff0b382db6c2050be4672f5f396194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6ff0b382db6c2050be4672f5f3961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e7f03382db6c2050be4672f5f39619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"eff03382db6c2050be4672f5f39619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"eff03382db6c2050be4672f5f39619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7ff0b382db6c2050be4672f5f396196b","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ENGG4600.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

contentlets.description:

Benefits for participating can include unique opportunities and experiences, mentoring by academic supervisors, guest speakers, and funding opportunities and engagement with industry partners.

Under the guidance of academic mentors and industry mentors, this course provides a vehicle for guided but independent group project work on varying briefs. The learning and effort in the course is largely group-based, with group members ideally being drawn from different discipline areas. Students will develop their skills in critical thinking, problem definition, creative and systematic design, precise written and oral technical communication skills, and professional skills including communication and team organisation and coordination. The course allows students to design, build and research a variety of projects. 

Prerequisite conditions:

UNSW Engineering students prerequisites: (Successful completion of ENGG1000 or enrolled in a Food Science or Computer Science plan) AND successful completion of at least 114 UOC AND enrolled in a program offered by the Faculty of Engineering.

UNSW Medicine students (program 3805 or 3856) must have demonstrated adequate performance with teamwork in every course during their first year to be eligible to participate in Vertically Integrated Courses: ENGG2600, ENGG3600, ENGG4600.

Medicine students must also be eligible to overload during year 3 based on the general education requirements for BSc (Med) Hons.

Students from other UNSW Faculties may apply to join the ChallENG program as a General Education elective. Students should ensure their program requires a General Education elective prior to application.

Note: WAM will be considered in all student applications for enrolment in this course.

Complex systems and systems of systems are numerous and include space systems, health systems, structural systems and transportation systems. The engineering of these complex systems must ensure that many complex parts are properly engineered to work together in order to meet the design requirements. Systems engineering is the collection of principles, processes, guidelines, practices, and frameworks that guide the design and engineering of complex systems in order to ensure they are successfully delivered. This course will introduce students to the discipline of Systems Engineering and is relevant to all areas of engineering. It will cover, amongst others, topics such as Requirements Development and Analysis, Functional Analysis, System Architecting, System Design, System Integration and System Validation. It will also look at trade studies and risk analysis. It will also provide concrete examples from various disciplines.

"Exposure to professional engineering practice is a key element in differentiating a professional engineering degree from an applied science degree." (Engineers Australia)


In order to satisfy the EA expectations of a graduating engineer, students need to have exposure to professional practice. At UNSW, this means at least the equivalent of 60 days of relevant Industrial Training. Students get first-hand experience in an engineering-practice environment.


This course is for students to submit their Final Industrial Training report. Completion of the Industrial training pre-requisite modules must be completed prior to seeking pre-approval for a placement. Once approval has been given and students have completed their 60 days of Industrial Training, students are required to submit the Final Industrial Training report via the ENGG4999 Moodle site. The Faculty Industrial Training Administration team will enrol the student into ENGG4999.

"Exposure to professional engineering practice is a key element in differentiating a professional engineering degree from an applied science degree." (Engineers Australia)

In order to satisfy the EA expectations of a graduating engineer, students need to have exposure to professional practice. At UNSW, this means at least the equivalent of 60 days of relevant Industrial Training. Students get first-hand experience in an engineering-practice environment.

This course is for students to submit their Final Industrial Training report. Completion of the Industrial training pre-requisite modules must be completed prior to seeking pre-approval for a placement. Once approval has been given and students have completed their 60 days of Industrial Training, students are required to submit the Final Industrial Training report via the ENGG4999 Moodle site. The Faculty Industrial Training Administration team will enrol the student into ENGG4999.
